Award.AwardTitle: Fully nonlinear elliptic equations in geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Differential equations play a central role in mathematics and its applications, for example, in differential geometry and mathematical physics. Fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic equations are some of the main equations under current investigations by researchers. Building on the recent progress, in this project the principal investigator will establish general existence and regularity results for these equations on real or complex manifolds and develop technical tools which can be applied to solve other types of equations. Results in this project will yield interesting applications in geometry and help to understand general partial differential equations.

A central issue in solving fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic equations is to establish a priori estimates which present great challenges due to the high nonlinearity of the equations and the general geometry of the manifolds as well as their boundaries. The project's goal is to search for new methods to overcome these difficulties. In particular, it will identify the optimal conditions under which one can solve the equations on general manifolds. The principal investigator also plans to study a very general class of equations on which few results are known, and attack some difficult problems in complex geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerns a wide class of nonlinear partial differential equations on general real or complex manifolds. These equations include the classical Laplace equation and Monge-Ampere equation as special cases and arise in a variety of fields in mathematics and applications. They were first systematically studied in Euclidean space by Luis Caffarelli, Louis Nirenberg and Joel Spruck in a series of papers of far-reaching influences published in 1980's. Since then the fundamental structure conditions introduced in their work have become standard in the literature of fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic equations.
In this project we dealt with the equations on general real or complex manifolds (which are "curved spaces" looking more like mountains than flat planes). We studied both the Dirichlet problem on manifolds with boundary and equations on closed manifolds. In both cases it is challenging to solve the equations due to the presence of curvature of the underlying manifolds and the arbitrary shape of the boundary. We developed crucial techniques which enabled us to overcome these difficulties and establish general existence results under conditions almost optimal in the sense that the results no longer hold if any one of the conditions is dropped.
The ideas and techniques we introduced in the project have been applied by others to successfully treat equations arising from important problems in geometry and other fileds. It is reasonable to expect further applications.
